questions.question:
Question 1: What is the technique of stimulating uterine contractions in a pregnant patient prior to the 
onset of spontaneous labour known as?
questions.explanation:
The technique of stimulating uterine contractions prior to the onset of spontaneous labor 
is known as induction of labor. It can be done irrespective of the rupture of membranes. Augmentation is the enhancement of spontaneous contractions that are considered inadequate 
because of failed cervical dilation and fetal descent.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is not a contraindication for the induction of labor?

options.d: History of lower transverse cesarean section in last three pregnancies

questions.explanation:
227 
Sold by @itachibot Heart disease is currently not considered a contraindication for the induction of labor. Vaginal 
delivery is preferred in such patients.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 30-year-old G3P2 woman was admitted to the ward at 40 weeks of gestation for induction 
of labor. You were asked to calculate her Bishop's score. What should be the minimum score 
before performing this procedure?
questions.explanation:
The minimum Bishop Score required before proceeding with induction of labour is 6. A Bishop score >8 conveys a high likelihood of a successful induction. The latest guidelines 
state that a cut-off score of 6 can be used to choose between pharmacological and mechanical 
methods of induction. This score is calculated based on the: • station of the fetal head • dilation of cervix • cervical length • position of cervix • consistency of the cervix. This score is an important determinant of a successful induction.

questions.question:
Question 4: During rounds in the postnatal ward, you notice a patient's case sheet mentioning she had 
uterine tachysystole following labor induction. What is the criteria for this diagnosis? 221 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: More than 5 contractions in a 5-min period
options.b: More than 5 contractions in a 10-min period
options.c: More than 10 contractions in a 5-min period
options.d: More than 10 contractions in a 10-min period

questions.explanation:
Uterine tachysystole is defined as >5 contractions in a 10 min period and may occur in 
spontaneous or stimulated labor. It should always be qualified by the presence or absence of fetal 
heart rate abnormalities. Tachysystole interrupts maternal blood flow to the placenta during 
contractions and may lead to a reduction in fetal oxygenation. It is also associated with placental 
abruption. It is caused by pharmacological agents used for cervical ripening and induction such as 
misoprostol (both oral and vaginal) and dinoprostone. Management includes stopping oxytocin 
infusion and terbutaline 0.25 mg SC.

questions.question:
Question 5: A primigravida was admitted to the labor room at 41 weeks of gestation for the induction of 
labor. What is the dose of misoprostol used for this procedure?
questions.explanation:
Misoprostol (PGE1) is given as 25mcg 3-6 hourly vaginally or 25mcg 2 hourly orally for the 
induction of labor. It is associated with the following side effects: • Uterine tachysystole • Meconium stained amniotic fluid • Uterine rupture 228 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: Oxytocin is being given for augmentation of labour in a multigravida admitted to the labour 
room. Which of the following is not a mechanism of action of this drug?

options.a: Receptor mediation through G-protein coupled receptors
options.b: Activation of voltage mediated Ca channel

questions.explanation:
Competitive blocking of acetylcholine is not a mechanism of action of oxytocin. Mechanism of action of oxytocin is as follows: • Receptor mediation through G protein-coupled receptors • Activation of voltage-gated Ca channel leading to calcium entry • Prostaglandin production by a positive feedback mechanism. This induces production of more 
prostaglandins and stronger contractions.

questions.question:
Question 7: In which of the following patients would you perform a controlled artificial rupture of 
membranes?

options.a: G3P2 lady with absent fetal cardiac activity at 34 weeks of gestation
options.b: Multigravida with HIV at 36 weeks of gestation
options.c: G2P1 lady with AFI of 28 cm at 38 weeks of gestation
options.d: Term primigravida with red, tender, vesicular lesions on her vulva

questions.explanation:
Controlled artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) is performed in a patient with amniotic fluid 
index (AFI)  25 cm. This points towards a diagnosis of polyhydramnios. This is because if ARM is not done under controlled conditions in these patients, it can cause 
sudden decompression of the fetus. This can lead to abruption of placenta. Contraindications to ARM: • Intrauterine fetal death • Active genital herpes infection • Maternal HIV-AIDS

questions.question:
Question 8: 222 
Sold by @itachibot An obstetrician performs the following procedure for labor induction in a patient. Which of 
the following is false about the reflex elicited here?

options.a: Occurs due to pressure at the external os of cervix
options.b: It is associated with increased level of PGF2
options.c: Artificial rupture of membranes initiates this reflex
options.d: It is an example of positive feedback mechanism

questions.explanation:
Stripping of membranes is being depicted in the image, which elicits the Ferguson reflex. It is also 
known as the fetal ejection reflex and is seen due to the pressure at the internal os of the cervix. It is associated with an increase in blood levels of a prostaglandin F2 metabolite, also known as 
dinoprost. This is released due to mechanical stretching of the internal os. This enhances the 
uterine activity and causes release of more prostaglandins. It is an example of a positive feedback 
mechanism.

questions.question: Question 9: All of the following are true about laminaria tents except:

options.b: Leads to the release of endogenous prostaglandins

questions.explanation:
The Bishop's score is rapidly improved by the use of laminaria tents. It is a mechanical cervical dilator and acts by hygroscopic osmotic action, leading to slow 
dilatation of the cervix. The gentle dilatation by laminaria tents induces an endogenous synthesis 
of prostaglandins causing a softening of the cervix. This is useful in cervical ripening before 
induction of labour. 229 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: A nursing assistant posted in the obstetric care unit was asked to plot a partograph to 
monitor the progress of labour. Where should she start marking the cervical dilatation?
questions.explanation:
In a partograph, the first marking of cervical dilatation should be made on the left of the alert 
line. In a normal partograph, the plotting remains on the left of the alert line.

questions.question:
Question 11: You are monitoring the number, duration, and intensity of uterine contractions in a 
34-year-old G2P1 woman with a term pregnancy. How long should they last for you to classify 
them as moderate?
questions.explanation:
Moderate uterine contractions last for 20–40 s. Weak contractions last for <20 s and strong contractions are >40 s. During active labour, uterine contractions are 5 min apart for 1 hour, i.e.,  12 contractions in 1 
hour. This is accompanied by cervical dilatation of 3–5 cm. 230 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: A G2P1 woman with polyhydramnios, presents to the clinic with respiratory distress at 38 
weeks of gestation. The obstetrician plans for induction of labor. What is a safe method of 
induction in this patient?

options.c: Abdominal amniocentesis followed by oxytocin drip

questions.explanation:
Abdominal amniocentesis followed by oxytocin drip is a safe method for induction of labor in 
polyhydramnios. Abdominal amniocentesis drains a good amount of liquor (amnioreduction), after which the 
oxytocin infusion can be started. This will minimize the sudden decompression and reduce the 
risk of placental separation, cord prolapse and change in lie of the fetus. Although polyhydramnios does not constitute an absolute contraindication for the application of 
prostaglandins, these substances should be administered with caution. There is a marked increase 
in the incidence of postpartum hemorrhage and amniotic fluid embolism with their use. 
Hence, amnioreduction is a preferred mode of treatment in polyhydramnios.

questions.question:
Question 13: Given below is the partograph of a primigravida in labor. What should be the next step in 
managing her condition? 224 
Sold by @itachibot

options.d: Induction of labor by mechanical methods

questions.explanation:
As the plotting on the above partograph has crossed the action line, the next step of management 
is Caesarean section.

questions.question: Question 14: What is the half-life of oxytocin?
questions.explanation:
The half-life of oxytocin is approximately 3–5 min. Therefore, once oxytocin infusion is stopped, 
its concentration in plasma rapidly falls.

questions.question:
Question 15: During your OBG rotations, one of the senior residents asks you to induce labor in a 
primigravida admitted at 40 weeks of gestation. Identify the following device that you will use 
for the same. 225 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
This is an image of a cervidil vaginal insert. It is used for cervical ripening and improves the 
Bishop's score. It contains 10 mg of dinoprostone designed to release at a rate of approximately 0.3 mg/hr over 
10-hours.

questions.question:
Question 16: According to the WHO Labour Care Guidelines, documentation of labour progress begins at a 
cervical dilatation of -
questions.explanation:
According to the WHO Labour Care Guidelines, documentation of labour progress begins at a 
cervical dilatation of 5cm. WHO Labour Care Guidelines: • Time axis - examination findings are plotted every one hour 231 
Sold by @itachibot • Alert column- has values which if reached indicates the need for urgent medical intervention • Active first stage - findings are plotted every hour upto 12 hours. If the first stage continues, a 
new sheet is used. • Second stage - plotted every hour upto 3 hours 1) Section 1: Preliminary information Name, parity, labour onset, active labour diagnosis (date), ruptured membranes (date&time), 
risk factors 2) Section 2: Supportive care • Companionship • Pain relief • Oral fluid • Posture 3) Section 3: Baby • Baseline FHR • FHR deceleration • Amniotic fluid • Fetal position • Caput • Moulding 4) Section 4: Vitals Pulse, SBP, DBP, temperature, and urine for proteins are recorded every 4 hours 5) Section 5: Labour progress • Count the number of uterine contractions over a 10-minute period. • Assess the duration of contractions • Cervical dilatation: starts at 5 cm and is plotted as ˜; it is assessed every hour. For example - if 
the cervical dilatation remains at 5cm for  6hrs, it indicates the need for urgent intervention. 
Similarly, the cut-offs for - 6cm is  5hrs; ™cm is  3hrs; 8cm is  2.5hrs; šcm is  2 hrs • Descent - plotted as O 6) Section 6: Medication • Oxytocin • Medicine • IV fluids ™) Section ™: Shared decision making • Assessment • Plan 232 
Sold by @itachibot *Fetal position, vitals of the mother and cervical dilatation can be assessed at 4 hourly if the 
labour is progressing adequately *If birth is not completed by 3 hours from the start of the active second stage in nulliparous and 2 
hours in multiparous women, intervention is needed

questions.question:
Question 17: Which of the following modifications have been made in the WHO Labour care guidelines as 
compared to the modified partograph

options.a: Forceful adduction by extension of legs on abdomen
options.b: Forceful adduction by flexion of legs on abdomen
options.c: Forceful abduction of legs by extending them on abdomen
options.d: Forceful abduction of legs by flexing them on abdomen
